borrelia_burgdorferi: The patient is a 45-year-old male presenting with a 10-day history of progressive fatigue, mild headaches, and generalized malaise. He describes the headaches as dull, occurring intermittently throughout the day. Approximately seven days ago, he noticed an erythematous rash on his left calf. The rash initially presented as a small red spot but expanded over the week into a larger "bull's-eye" pattern, now measuring approximately 10 cm in diameter. The patient mentions the rash is not painful but is slightly warm to touch. He recalls removing a tick from his leg around two weeks ago but did not experience any immediate symptoms. He denies fever, chills, joint pain, or neck stiffness.
staphylococcus_aureus: Sarah Thompson, a 27-year-old caucasian female nurse, presents with a complaint of a swollen, painful, and erythematous area on her right forearm that has developed over the past three days. She reports the onset of low-grade fever with temperatures ranging from 99.5°F to 100.3°F and occasional chills. The area initially started as a small, tender bump following minor abrasion during her recent gym workout, which she attributes to equipment contact. She has tried warm compresses without relief. Sarah denies any systemic symptoms like nausea, vomiting, or respiratory distress. She has not used any oral antibiotics and has only applied topical hydrocortisone cream sporadically for recurring dermatitis flares.
escherichia_coli:
John Doe, a 65-year-old Hispanic male, presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, chills, and difficulty urinating. He reports these symptoms began suddenly two days ago, with fever spikes up to 101.8°F and increasing malaise. John also mentions experiencing lower abdominal pain and discomfort during urination, which he associates with previous UTIs. There is no nausea or vomiting, but he has noted reduced appetite and fatigue. 

He has a history of type 2 diabetes with poor glycemic control and cirrhosis, both contributing to his immune compromise. The patient has experienced recurrent UTIs in the past year, culminating in his recent hospitalization for related complications.
nocardia_species: Maria Hernandez, a 58-year-old Hispanic female with a history of COPD and rheumatoid arthritis managed with corticosteroids, presents with complaints of persistent cough and breathlessness that have worsened over the past three weeks. She describes the cough as initially nonproductive but recently has noticed occasional blood-streaked sputum. She reports intermittent fevers and night sweats, alongside increasing fatigue and unintentional weight loss of approximately 5 pounds over the last month. Maria has a longstanding history of diabetes and uses metformin for management, noting that her blood sugars have been more erratic with these recent illnesses.
streptococcus_pneumoniae: Robert Lewis, a 72-year-old African American male with a history of chronic heart failure, chronic kidney disease stage 3, and type 2 diabetes, presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of productive cough, which has become increasingly purulent and occasionally blood-tinged. He reports associated symptoms including fever (maximum temperature recorded at home: 101.2°F), chills, dyspnea, and pleuritic chest pain. He has experienced fatigue, reduced appetite, and has felt generally unwell over the past week. No significant headaches or neurological symptoms are noted, but he has had episodes of confusion likely related to infection and dehydration.
hsv-1: Emily Carter, a 28-year-old Caucasian female graphic designer, presents with painful oral lesions and fever, which began three days ago. She reports experiencing tingling and burning sensations on her lips, followed by the development of vesicular lesions at the vermilion border. These lesions progressed to crusted sores. Initially, she also noted mild fever peaking at 100.2°F, fatigue, and some difficulty swallowing. Emily recalls having similar outbreaks of herpes labialis during periods of high stress in her past. She denies any recent episodes of pharyngitis or genital lesions and has been using topical docosanol cream, but this outbreak seems more persistent and uncomfortable.
influenza_a: George Thompson, a 68-year-old Caucasian male, presents with a 3-day history of acute onset fever, chills, myalgia, and non-productive cough. He reports feeling exceptionally fatigued, with generalized body aches and a persistent headache. George initially experienced nasal congestion and a sore throat, but these have subsided as systemic symptoms intensified. He mentions shortness of breath exacerbated by exertion, likely worsened by his underlying COPD and heart failure. There is no history of color changes in sputum or chest pain, but he acknowledges an increased feeling of “tightness” in his chest. This is his first significant illness since a pneumonia episode two years ago.
hiv: Linda Martinez, a 52-year-old Hispanic female and healthcare assistant, presents with a two-week history of persistent fatigue, generalized malaise, and weight loss of approximately 5 pounds. She describes intermittent episodes of fevers and night sweats. She also notes a mild sore throat and a new rash over her trunk. Linda has experienced recurrent oral thrush despite good oral hygiene, prompting her to seek medical attention. She reports occasional nausea but denies vomiting or diarrhea. Linda recently initiated antiretroviral therapy following her HIV diagnosis but feels her symptoms may have persisted due to untreated or resistant infections.
ebv: Jason Lee, a 19-year-old Asian American male college student, presents with a one-week history of sore throat, fever, and fatigue. He describes the onset of symptoms with generalized malaise and muscle aches, followed by a progressively worsening sore throat, which makes swallowing difficult. Jason has also noted swollen glands in his neck and low-grade fevers peaking in the late afternoon around 102°F. Recently, he has observed a mild skin rash on his trunk. He denies respiratory symptoms like cough or shortness of breath but mentions feeling very tired and having reduced appetite.
candida_albicans: Sophia Adams, a 36-year-old African American female legal secretary with a history of moderately controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus, presents with a five-day history of increased discomfort and burning sensation in the vaginal area. She reports experiencing intense pruritus and a thick, cottage cheese-like discharge. The symptoms started shortly after she completed a course of antibiotics following her appendectomy three weeks ago. Additionally, she mentions dysuria and vulvar irritation. Her urinary catheter was removed last week, and she has adhered to her diabetes medication but has struggled with diet control post-surgery.
aspergillus_fumigatus: Michael Johnson, a 58-year-old Caucasian male with a history of COPD, diabetes, and recent chemotherapy for non-Hodgkin lymphoma, presents with a two-week history of persistent cough, worsening dyspnea on exertion, and low-grade fevers. He reports increasing fatigue and has noted some weight loss over the past month. Despite regular use of inhaled bronchodilators, his respiratory symptoms have intensified, prompting him to seek medical attention. He denies chest pain but mentions occasional hemoptysis.
plasmodium_falciparum: James Anderson, a 34-year-old Caucasian male environmental scientist, presents with a 5-day history of acute onset fever, chills, and profuse night sweats after returning from a three-week research trip in sub-Saharan Africa. He reports severe headaches, generalized weakness, and muscle aches. Initially, James experienced insomnia and felt increasingly fatigued, managing only minimal daily activities. He also notes experiencing episodes of nausea and mild abdominal discomfort but denies any diarrhea. Despite taking antihistamines for what he assumed were allergy-related symptoms, his condition has not improved.
taenia_solium: Maria Gonzalez, a 45-year-old Hispanic female chef, presents with a two-month history of intermittent headaches, mild fever, and episodes of dizziness. More recently, she has experienced occasional nausea and vomiting, along with subtle changes in vision. Maria reports difficulty concentrating and periodic weakness in her right arm, which started approximately one month after returning from rural Mexico. She recalls consuming several local pork dishes that may have been inadequately cooked. Despite using over-the-counter analgesics, her symptoms have persisted and now seem to fluctuate in intensity.
